title: pilot-analysis
text:
Purchase frequency
This scale assesses how frequently people buy each of the foods. 1 - never, 2 - less than once a month, 3 - about once a month, 4 - 2-3 times a month, 5 - once a week, 6 - Multiple times a week.
Products should be bought quite frequently as that was a criteria for the initial selection.

title: pilot-analysis
text:
Correct storage per food item
Below shows whether products were stored in the correct location. We distinguish five possible location:

Fridge
Freezer
Kitchen counter
Pantry or kitchen cupboard
Cellar

Criteria are based on information from the Austrian BMK, Gesundheit.gv.at and The Netherlands Nutrition Centre.

Cucumbers are often stored in the fridge. However, they are sensitive to cold and will only last up to 5 days in the fridge. They are best stored at 10-13 degrees, where they will last up to 3 weeks, but a cold place in the kitchen is still preferable over the fridge.
Apples are often stored on the kitchen counter. However, they are best kept between 2-7 degrees, in the fridge. This also makes it more likely they stay away from other fruits and vegetables which are sensitive to ethylene.

Tomatoes are missing from the list, but may also be tricky. They are best stored outside of the fridge.
Most other foods are stored correctly and less important to focus an intervention on. Though it may still be worthwhile to inform consumers that bread freezer well, potatoes should go somewhere cool, dry and dark and bananas should not go in the fridge.

title: pilot-analysis
text:
Storage per product
This further breaks down where each product is stored.

title: pilot-analysis
text:
Foods going off
This figure shows mean scores for the question how often does a food goes bad before being able to finish it, rated on a 7-point scale from 1 - Never to 7 - (almost) always.
People generally underestimate how much food they throw away, so this has to be taken with a grain of salt, but gives an indication.
Overall, people indicate that their food very rarely goes bad before use, with the overall mean falling somewhere between almost never and rarely. Regardless, people do let food go off more often than it should happen.










Overall frequency of each rating


Rating
Frequency




Never
260


Almost Never
348


Rarely
200


Sometimes
176


Fairly Often
59


Very Often
11


Always
3

title: pilot-analysis
text:
Correct packaging per food item
This shows whether food products were packaged correctly when stored. Below is more detailed information about how the products are stored. This question was only asked for foods where packaging matters.
It is split into best/adequate/poor, because in many cases there is an optimal storage condition, but alternatives are also not that bad.
Of note are:

Bread is often stored airtight, but this traps moisture and will lead to it moulding quicker.
A head of lettuce is best stored with the stalk in water, though this is very rarely done
fresh herbs are best wrapped in a moist kitchen towel or placed in a glass of water, but many do not
Bananas are best stored with the top wrapped to stop ethylene from spreading, but no one indicated doing this.

title: pilot-analysis
text:
Storage specifics per food
This breaks down further how some of the products are stored.

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Show code
library(data.table)
library(dplyr)
library(gtsummary)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(tibble)
library(psych)
library(careless)
library(kableExtra)
library(broom)
library(purrr)




Show code
wd <- list()
wd$data   <- "C:/Users/huism080/OneDrive - Wageningen University & Research/Research/Study-3/analysis/data/"
wd$output <- "C:/Users/huism080/OneDrive - Wageningen University & Research/Research/Study-3/analysis/output/"

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Show code
library(data.table)
library(dplyr)
library(gtsummary)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(tibble)
library(psych)
library(careless)
library(kableExtra)
library(broom)
library(purrr)




Show code
wd <- list()
wd$data   <- "C:/Users/huism080/OneDrive - Wageningen University & Research/Research/Study-3/analysis/data/"
wd$output <- "C:/Users/huism080/OneDrive - Wageningen University & Research/Research/Study-3/analysis/output/"

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Data Loading and Preparation


Show code
raw <- fread(paste0(wd$data, "pilot_onboarding_complete_20250923.csv"))

# Check attention check (3 people failed but responses seem genuine)
failed_att <- raw %>% 
  filter(Status == 0 & Finished == 1 & consent == 1) %>% 
  filter(motivation_10 != 3)




Show code
df <- raw %>% 
  filter(Status == 0 & Finished == 1 & consent == 1) %>% 
  select(36,37,45:55,57:61) %>% 
  mutate(across(c(3, 5:15,17), as.numeric)) %>%  # Convert to numeric first
  mutate(
    # Create motivation composites - now variables are numeric
    mot_ex = (motivation_1 + motivation_2 + motivation_3) / 3,
    mot_id = (motivation_4 + motivation_5 + motivation_6) / 3,
    mot_in = (motivation_7 + motivation_8 + motivation_9) / 3,
    # Factor variables
    condition = factor(ifelse(is.na(`Q32_Click Count`), 0, 1), 
                      labels = c("Intrinsic", "Identified")),
    gender = factor(gender, levels = 4:7, 
                   labels = c("Male", "Female", "Non-binary", "Other")),
    employ = factor(employ)
  ) %>% 
  rownames_to_column(var = "id")

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Sample Characteristics


Show code
df %>% 
  select(condition, gender, age, employ) %>% 
  tbl_summary(by = condition) %>% 
  add_overall() %>% 
  modify_header(label ~ "**Variable**") %>% 
  as_kable_extra() %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Psychometric Analysis

Factor Structure


Show code
fa_results <- df %>% 
  select(motivation_1:motivation_9) %>% 
  fa(nfactors = 3, rotate = "varimax")

fa_results$loadings %>% 
  unclass() %>% 
  as.data.frame() %>% 
  rownames_to_column("Item") %>% 
  kable(digits = 3, caption = "Factor Loadings for Motivation Items") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))

Internal Consistency


Show code
reliability_data <- data.frame(
  Scale = c("Extrinsic", "Identified", "Intrinsic"),
  Alpha = c(
    alpha(df %>% select(motivation_1:motivation_3))$total$raw_alpha,
    alpha(df %>% select(motivation_4:motivation_6))$total$raw_alpha,
    alpha(df %>% select(motivation_7:motivation_9))$total$raw_alpha
  ),
  Items = c("1-3", "4-6", "7-9")
)

reliability_data %>%
  kable(digits = 3, caption = "Internal Consistency (Cronbach's Alpha)") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Descriptive Statistics

Motivation Scores by Condition


Show code
df %>%
  select(condition, mot_ex, mot_id, mot_in) %>%
  group_by(condition) %>%
  summarise(
    across(starts_with("mot"), 
           list(Mean = ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE), 
                SD = ~ sd(.x, na.rm = TRUE)), 
           .names = "{.fn}_{.col}"),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  kable(digits = 2, caption = "Descriptive Statistics by Condition") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))



Descriptive Statistics by Condition


condition

Motivation Scores Visualization


Show code
df %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(mot_ex, mot_id, mot_in),
               names_to = "motivation_type",
               names_prefix = "mot_",
               values_to = "score") %>%
  mutate(motivation_type = case_when(
    motivation_type == "ex" ~ "Extrinsic",
    motivation_type == "id" ~ "Identified", 
    motivation_type == "in" ~ "Intrinsic"
  )) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = motivation_type, y = score, fill = condition)) +
  stat_summary(geom = "col", fun = mean, position = "dodge", alpha = 0.8) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", fun.data = mean_se, 
               position = position_dodge(0.9), width = 0.2) +
  labs(title = "Mean Motivation Scores by Condition",
       x = "Motivation Type", y = "Mean Score", fill = "Condition") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")





Mean motivation scores by experimental condition

title: Effect of onboarding on motivation types
text:
Inferential Statistics

Main Effects: Condition on Motivation


Show code
aov_ex <- aov(mot_ex ~ condition, data = df)
tidy(aov_ex) %>%
  kable(digits = 3, caption = "ANOVA: Condition → Extrinsic Motivation") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))

Demographic Predictors of Motivation

Extrinsic Motivation


Show code
aov_ex_demo <- aov(mot_ex ~ gender + age + employ, data = df)
tidy(aov_ex_demo) %>%
  filter(term != "Residuals") %>%
  kable(digits = 3, caption = "ANOVA: Demographics → Extrinsic Motivation") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"))

Visualization of Significant Effects

Show code
# Age effect on extrinsic motivation
p1 <- ggplot(df, aes(x = age, y = mot_ex)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE) +
  labs(title = "Age × Extrinsic Motivation", x = "Age", y = "Score") +
  theme_minimal()

# Gender effect on identified motivation  
p2 <- ggplot(df, aes(x = gender, y = mot_id)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7, fill = "lightblue") +
  labs(title = "Gender × Identified Motivation", x = "Gender", y = "Score") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

print(p1)
print(p2)







Demographic effects on motivation







Demographic effects on motivation
